body: I'll keep an eye, thanks!
LGTM. waiting for tests to pass. Thanks!

FYI, there's an issue on OSX machine for Travis CI. As Jenkins passed, I think we are good to go.

LGTM
@amarouni note for future contribution: it's better to keep your commits in the head log using git rebase. It's largely easier to squash.
No problem, thanks for your contribution !
I think the travis build failure is unrelated. As soon as it's approved I'll submit a back-port to Cloud DataFlow.
thanks!

@jbonofre 
Does it make any sense to add DDL (drop existing collection, ...) options to the IO ?
(These would be executed once the IO is instantiated on the driver side.)
Or it makes more sense to keep these outside of the IO ?
LGTM
A good way to keep the PR fresh and also to get Jenkins to run again is to rebase against master.
Let me know if I can help with the configuration issue.
@kennknowles it is an address resolution issue on the jenkins environment, we are still investigating it. Can you please look at the other questions or comments that are related to the runner itself?
@amarouni it's a good idea. My plan is first to complete this PR (the split and estimated size should be improved, I'm working on it). The DDL option could be part of a new PR. WDYT ?

org/apache/beam/runners/spark/io/hadoop/HadoopIO.java should use PBegin
org/apache/beam/sdk/transforms/Create.java should use PBegin

R: @dhalperi
LGTM

Thanks for the contribution.

In the future, just use commits tagged with !fixup at the beginning and when merging a committer should squash those commits.

For large CLs, preserving the order of the commits makes the reviewers life a lot easier because then they can see what they have changed.

Also, if you haven't taken a look at the Apache Beam Contribution Guide:
http://beam.incubator.apache.org/contribute/contribution-guide/
@lukecwik : Will take care of it next time

I made a few fixups, and merged. Thanks @ppastuszkaocado !

Hmm. The test suite still failed after I made this change, even though it compiled and passed all unit tests. I have disabled the build for now, and I will leave it up to @manuzhang to figure out the rest. Sorry I couldn't figure it out!

The unit tests fail on Jenkins due to misconfiguration and unexpected host name resolution in that environment (builds.apache.org label beam). `InetAddress.getLocalHost()` returns valid resolvable `InetAddress`, but that address is not among interfaces that network server that binds to 0:0:0:0 listens to. Here is an output of few commands:

```
InetAddress.getLocalHost():
214.175.197.104.bc.googleusercontent.com/104.197.175.214

hostname
jenkins-beam2.apache.org

hostname -i
104.197.175.214

hostname -I
10.128.0.2 172.17.0.1 
```

Note that `InetAddress.getLocalHost()` result is not the same as the output of `hostname`. IP address provided by `hostname -i` is not among addresses returned by `hostname -I`. And the issue seems to start from the fact that `hostname` returns name that resolves to an external IP address (docker host?) with reverse DNS pointing to  214.175.197.104.bc.googleusercontent.com.

LGTM 
Had to make the same change in https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/897

R: @dhalperi

Hmm. It would be cleaner if rather than have a zero-args constructor and defaults in the class, your static factory method simply passed in all the defaults to the real constructor. Then you need not worry about the initialization state of any parameters.

See, for example, [`BigtableIO`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigtable/BigtableIO.java#L154)

also @iemejia PTAL as well since you handled #859

I proposed to remove this because I was bombarded by this log (when I tried to read an empty topic), so my initial reaction was to change the logging level to something lower (e.g. debug or trace). But then I thought a bit about it and I could not see an interesting use case where logging ´nothing happens' made sense to me (but I could have missed something).
I am just curious about your current use case, I am not against this behavior returning (with a lower log level), but I would like to understand why this is useful.

@iemejia 
I found it useful for black box tests

Global recap (because comment on changed code is hidden): 

**getCredential(GcpOptions options)** -> keyFile or accountName is give -> check at least that the keyFile is given (**required** for JSON and P12)
**getCredentialFromFile** -> check if it's a JSON keyFile (**no** accountName **allowed**) or p12 keyFile (accountName **required**)

Because keyFile is checked of in getCredential @Nullable could be removed from keyFile in getCredentialFromFile.

R: @tgroh (initially)

The TypeDescriptor could be an alternative field/in addition to the Coder, where you add an `Optional<TypeDescriptor<T>>` field to the `Values` PTransform. The Coder need not be available at transform creation time but at transform apply time, at which point you have access to the Pipeline (and can perform coder inference)

Adding this method should also remove the ability to call `Create.of()` - as such, `Create.of(T...)` should be changed to `Create.of(T, T...)` to ensure that there is always at least one element or a Coder has been provided, and `Create.of(Iterable<T>)` should add a `checkArgument(!Iterables.isEmpty(elems))`
